title: Anti-Vaxxers Ironically Fund Study That Finds No Link Between Vaccines And Autism
paragraphs: A new study has found that exercise is helpful with addressing erectile dysfunction, and suggests it should be added to the treatment regime.
A recent study showed thatpeople who practice Japan's recommended dietary habits are 15 percent less likely to die of diseases.
For patients with type 2 diabetes, the answer to losing weight may be H2O.
A new study has revealed that going for a run after learning could help with memory retention.
Has a recent clown-sighting trend created a fear of the masked jokers, or have we always been afraid of them?
Hormone fluctuation throughout your menstrual cycle influences brain growth.
Findings from a new study could help more women to overcome breast cancer.
A new product promises to make sex during menstruation less of a mess.
Researchers discovered hundreds of genes that could be connected with autism spectrum disorder.
Veterans did not respond well to Donald Trump's comments on PTSD, a common mental health disorder many soldiers face.
The WHO wants countries to start taxing sugary drinks, and use the revenue to fight health problems sugar may worsen.
This particular gene mutation may be linked to recurrent miscarriages during the first trimester.
Stress affects our bodies in lots of obvious ways, like making us hungry or sweaty, but other reactions are much stranger than that.
Millennials Are Tying The Knot Later In Life, But Why?
Millennials have a reputation for switching jobs and partners; could this alleged difficulty with commitment explain why they're getting married later?
Would Eating Human Brains Make You Sick?
Have a craving for human brains this Halloween?
Throughout history, people have attributed scary looking and unfamiliar illnesses to dark forces, including witches and demons.
People are generally aware of the most common causes of hallucinations, like schizophrenia and a really high fever.
But lesser known are the more rare causes; here are six you probably haven't heard about.

While every major health organization, researcher, and certified physician can agree that vaccines dont cause autism, the anti-vaxxers out there remain stalwart that somehow, the link must still exist, and its simply due to incorrect data that it hasnt been proven yet.
To most of us, it seems ludicrous that they cling to this notion, especially after scores of scientific evidence have proven that vaccines are entirely safe and do not cause autism.

The researchers examined 79 infant monkeys divided into six groups; two of the groups were given vaccines containing thimerosal an antiseptic and antifungal component that was removed from vaccines recently.

Two other groups were given the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine which is often cited by anti-vaxxers as a source of autism and the last two groups were given a saline injection as a control.

Their conclusion was straightforward: Neither the thimerosal-containing vaccines nor the MMR vaccines changed the behavior of the monkeys, and they didnt contribute at all to any shrinking of the hippocampus or other regions of the brain (which has, in the past, been associated with autism).
No behavioral changes were observed in the vaccinated animals, the authors write, nor were there neuropathological changes in the cerebellum, hippocampus, or amygdala.
This study does not support the hypothesis that thimerosal-containing vaccines and/or MMR vaccine play a role in the etiology of autism.
Despite the crystal clear conclusion, SafeMinds continues to argue that the results are controversial, still unclear, and open to interpretation.

col-lg-9"><div class="inner-wrap"><div id="block-system-main" class="block block-system first odd"><div class="content"> <article id="node-356232" class="node node-article left-sidebar view-mode-full full-article clearfix" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/NewsArticle"> <header><div class="category"> <span>The Grapevine</span></div><h1 class="node-title" itemprop="headline">Anti-Vaxxers Ironically Fund Study That Finds No Link Between Vaccines And Autism</h1><div class="byline"> <span class="date" itemprop="datePublished" datetime="2015-10-07T15:53:32-04:00">Oct 7, 2015 03:53 PM </span> By <span class="author"> <span itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemprop="author" itemscope=""><a href="/reporters/lecia-bushak" rel="author" itemprop="url">Lecia Bushak</a></span> </span></div><div class="image-wrapper" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/headline/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg"><div class="image"><picture itemprop="contentUrl" width="840" height="556" class="mapping-full"><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source srcset="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/full_breakpoints_theme_medicaldaily_desktop_1x/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 992px)" /><source srcset="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/full_breakpoints_theme_medicaldaily_tablet_1x/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 768px)" /><source srcset="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/full_breakpoints_theme_medicaldaily_narrow_1x/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 481px)" /><source srcset="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/full_breakpoints_theme_medicaldaily_mobile_1x/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 0px)" /><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img itemprop="contentUrl" width="840" height="556" class="mapping-full" src="http://images.medicaldaily.com/sites/medicaldaily.com/files/styles/headline/public/2015/10/07/macaque.jpg" alt="Macaque" title="" /></picture></div><div class="image-info"> <span class="image-caption" itemprop="caption"> Even when anti-vaxxers fund studies, they get the same results: Their hypothesis that vaccines cause autism has nothing to stand on. </span> <span class="image-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"> Pixabay, public domain </span></div></div> </header><div class="article-content"> <aside><ul class="share"><li class="comment"> <a href="#block-ibtmedia-facebook-facebook-comment">Comment</a></li><li class="fb"> <a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=" class="facebook" target="_blank">Share</a></li><li class="twt"> <a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Anti-Vaxxers+Ironically+Fund+Study+That+Finds+No+Link+Between+Vaccines+And+Autism+" class="twitter" target="_blank">Tweet</a></li><li class="ggl"> <a href="https://plus.google.com/share?url=" class="googleplus" target="_blank">Share</a></li><li class="mail"> <a href="mailto:?&subject=Anti-Vaxxers Ironically Fund Study That Finds No Link Between Vaccines And Autism&body=" class="mail" target="_blank">E-mail</a></li></ul> </aside><div class="article-body" itemprop="articleBody"><p>While every major health organization, researcher, and certified physician can agree that vaccines don’t cause autism, the anti-vaxxers out there remain stalwart that somehow, the link must still exist, and it’s simply due to incorrect data that it hasn’t been proven yet. To most of us, it seems ludicrous that they cling to this notion, especially after scores of scientific evidence have proven that vaccines are entirely safe and do not cause autism.</p><p>Now, it appears that the efforts of a certain group of anti-vaxxers have backfired, <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/anti-vaxxers-accidentally-fund-study-showing-theres-no-link-between-autism-and-379245? rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><em>Newsweek</em></a> reported. The anti-vaccination group, known as SafeMinds, funded a recent <a href="http://www.pnas.org/content/112/40/12498.full.pdf" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">study</a> published in the <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</em> that examined the link between autism and vaccines over the course of six years — and the study found no link at all, perhaps to their frustration.</p><p>The researchers examined 79 infant monkeys divided into six groups; two of the groups were given vaccines containing thimerosal — an antiseptic and antifungal component that was removed from vaccines recently. Two other groups were given the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine — which is often cited by anti-vaxxers as a source of autism — and the last two groups were given a saline injection as a control.</p><p>Their conclusion was straightforward: Neither the thimerosal-containing vaccines nor the MMR vaccines changed the behavior of the monkeys, and they didn’t contribute at all to any shrinking of the hippocampus or other regions of the brain (which has, in the past, been associated with autism).</p><p>“No behavioral changes were observed in the vaccinated animals,” the authors write, “nor were there neuropathological changes in the cerebellum, hippocampus, or amygdala. This study does not support the hypothesis that thimerosal-containing vaccines and/or MMR vaccine play a role in the etiology of autism.”</p><p>Despite the crystal clear conclusion, SafeMinds continues to argue that the results are “controversial,” still unclear, and open to interpretation.</p><p>“SafeMinds has concerns about changes in the study design protocol and analysis that may have led to these contradictory results,” the group said in a <a href="http://www.safeminds.org/blog/2015/10/05/why-arent-i-surprised-that-the-media-got-it-wrong-again/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">statement</a>. “We are in the process of collecting and reviewing additional information regarding this study.”</p><p>Fortunately, recent polls have shown that the numbers of warring <a href="http://www.medicaldaily.com/anti-vaxxers-decline-new-poll-finds-parents-are-gaining-confidence-benefits-vaccines-341860">anti-vaxxers are declining</a>. But there’s still a lot of work to be done to convince those who still cling to the vaccine-autism link. To start, it’s important to remind them that vaccines are <a href="http://www.medicaldaily.com/how-can-we-convince-anti-vaxxers-kids-need-get-vaccinated-show-them-why-its-important-345930">incredibly important to the health of all children</a>; but perhaps we can also note that even when they fund their own studies, the science says it all.</p><p>Source: Gabad B, Li W, Yazdani U, Grady S, Johnson T, Hammond J. Administration of thimerosal-containing vaccines to infant rhesus macaques does not result in autism-like behavior or neuropathology. <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</em>. 2015.</p></div> <aside><ul class="share"><li class="comment"> <a href="#block-ibtmedia-facebook-facebook-comment">Comment</a></li><li class="fb"> <a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=" class="facebook" target="_blank">Share</a></li><li class="twt"> <a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Anti-Vaxxers+Ironically+Fund+Study+That+Finds+No+Link+Between+Vaccines+And+Autism+" class="twitter" target="_blank">Tweet</a></li><li class="ggl"> <a href="https://plus.google.com/share?url=" class="googleplus" target="_blank">Share</a></li><li class="mail"> <a href="mailto:?&subject=Anti-Vaxxers Ironically Fund Study That Finds No Link Between Vaccines And Autism&body=" class="mail" target="_blank">E-mail</a></li></ul> </aside></div></article></div></div><div id="block-ibtmedia-dfp-ibtmedia-dfp-belowcontent" class="block block-ibtmedia-dfp even"><div class="content">
